content: Edit: I have reconsidered and will take your word on it. I still think it's sketchy though.
replyContent: That is a GENERIC system message for ALL accessibility services, it does not observe anything other than vol+/-. The app uses accessibility to detect volume key presses as that's the ONLY way to do it. If you're concerned, simply don't override the volume keys and use the floating trigger instead. The API doesn't allow isolated instances.

content: Awesome volume control. Using on a galaxy s10+
Happy New Year too!

Samsung Sound Assistant allows one to modify the system volume steps in order to offer more granularity for (low) volume adjustment. Unfortunately your application discards this setting and enforces Android default 15 steps. Otherwise the application design is great. You may allow your users to reorder the volume panels to improve further your interface. *** Following dev reply: Samsung SoundAssistant as found in the Playstore is indeed Samsung device centric but did not come preinstalled ***
replyContent:
Hi,

I can't see that app on the play store, is it a Samsung pre installed app?

The app requests the max level from the system and uses that as is, the steps are then in increments of 1 as you can't use decimals with the audiomanager API.

content: Works flawlessly!
Works great on my Nokia 6!
For this i give you 5 stars. But the other app no :(

I like the app as a more customizable replacement to the standard volume app. However I am not using it until it is able to adapt to the interval setting I have set for my volume control. I like a little more control than the giant moves with volume.
replyContent:
Hi Michael,

The intervals are entirely system defined and cannot be changed by an app.

The system reports the maximum volume for each stream and the app uses the system audio manager to change the volume in increments of 1, it's not possible to use decimals.

Thanks

Lee

There are a few ways around this, enable launch only on vol + or use power and gone for screen shots.

Cheers

Lee

content: Why does it make volume steps so small? Can I change step size? I need to present voldown like 60 times to go from 100% to 0%. I know I can just move the slider with my finger, but I'd like step size to be bigger, so that I can lower the volume with 6-8 button presses. Also, changing slider height in settings does nothing for me. Edit: but without your app when I change volume steps are much bigger. Could you just emulate it so that when I change volume once, app changes it x5?
replyContent:
Hi Gulam,

The volume steps are defined by the system, each stream returns a max & the app steps that in increments of 1, Android doesn't allow setting steps in decimals or increasing the max volume.

Cheers

Lee

replyContent: The app does offer split ring and notification volume on devices that support it. Cheers Lee Edit: Yes, volume butler isn't a native volume control app , it relies on constant running background services that intercept volume events and changes your device volume based on the app settings on the fly, that requires a lot of additional resources.

replyContent:
Hi Samuel,

The app doesn't do anything with notification or ring sounds, nor does it request to do so.

Each slider controls the volume for that individual stream and nothing more, the app uses the standard android audiomanager API & adjustStreamVolume()

Did you have the notification slider enabled? 

Thanks

Lee

replyContent:
Hi, This is your device incorrectly killing the accessibility service, no android device should do this, it's an OS issue and nothing to do with the app. Please try the force keep services alive option. 

This does not happen on HTC, Pixel, OnePlus or Sony devices.
